snippet: The pullout of capital from emerging markets eerily resembles the financial wave that emerged from Asia and swept across the globe in the late 1990s.
abstract: Eduardo Porter Economic scene column observes that pullout of capital from emerging financial markets, triggered by news that Federal Reserve has gradually started reducing amount of money it pumps into economy, eerily resembles financial wave that swept across the globe in late 1990s; reflects that current turmoil shows that the world seems unprepared again for long-term interest rates to rise.
lead_paragraph: The pullout of capital from emerging markets eerily resembles the financial wave that emerged from Asia and swept across the globe in the late 1990s.

headline.main: A World Unprepared, Again, for Rising Interest Rates
headline.print_headline: Unprepared, Again, for Rates to Rise

keywords.value: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
keywords.name: organizations
